comments.text:
Web apps are built around the assumption that each event handler runs to completion before the next event handler is run. Debugging a web app should not break that assumption, so Firebug uses nsIDOMWindowUtils.suppressEventHandling to freeze the debuggee while it is stopped at a breakpoint, etc.

Unfortunately, this also prevents the document from scrolling, so the developer can only see the portion of the document that happens to have been on screen when the breakpoint was hit. The rationale seems to be that, since we can't run the content's scroll event handlers, we shouldn't scroll.

It would be better to allow scrolling, but fire no event handlers in the content until event handling for that tab is enabled again, at which point we should fire a single scroll event (if necessary) that jumps the content to its present position.
comments.author: jimb@mozilla.com

comments.raw_text:
Not preventing scrolling would mean that all the mouse events etc should go to the page, but
somehow listeners should not fire. Also all the :hover and :active handling would become enabled too.. quite risky, IMO.

Also, "suppressEventHandling" should definitely prevent scrolling. It was originally added for
sync XHR, and while there is such active, user should not be able to scroll.

If Firebug needs to suppress only some event handling, perhaps it could create some
transparent "overlay" above the page to capture events and forward the needed events manually or
something like that.
comments.creator: bugs@pettay.fi
